paragraphs.text:
%md # Preparing Data for Import The easiest way to get your database tables populated is to import data from flat files (csv, etc.). Splice Machine imports data directly from HDFS, AWS S3, and Azure Block Storage. For this training we'll use S3, and the data we will import is already created and ready to load. If you want to learn more about how to import your own data, read on - otherwise continue to the [*Importing Data*](/#/notebook/2DVR1D5BP) notebook. ## Preparing Your Own Data for Import When you want to experiment with loading your own data from S3, you can follow the steps below to get your data into an S3 bucket. Additionally you will want to make sure your data is in a format that can be properly imported. Splice Machine has extensive online documentation on importing options and best practices.

Important: the flat files you use to import should be delimited (using comma, etc.), with newlines between each record.

To copy your database to S3, you need to have an AWS account with access to S3 buckets.

If you need assistance with copying your data to S3, please visit our splice-community Slack channel; if you've not already done so, you can register for this channel here.

## Copying Small Files From Your Local Machine For small files on your local machine, you may be able to use the AWS Web UI to upload your files: 1. Log in to your AWS account 2. Navigate to the S3 area 3. Create an S3 bucket, if necessary 4. Navigate to your S3 bucket 5. Click the `Upload` button 6. Select the files to copy or use drag-and-drop to copy them to S3" ## Copying Large Files The files that you want to import into your database are typically large and not located on your local computer; this makes it necessary to use the *AWS Command Line Interface* to copy these files to S3. The AWS CLI site, https://aws.amazon.com/cli/, shows you how to install and use this interface to copy your data up to an S3 bucket. Pr

msg.data:
Preparing Data for Import

The easiest way to get your database tables populated is to import data from flat files (csv, etc.). Splice Machine imports data directly from HDFS, AWS S3, and Azure Block Storage.

For this training we’ll use S3, and the data we will import is already created and ready to load. If you want to learn more about how to import your own data, read on - otherwise continue to the Importing Data notebook.

Preparing Your Own Data for Import

When you want to experiment with loading your own data from S3, you can follow the steps below to get your data into an S3 bucket. Additionally you will want to make sure your data is in a format that can be properly imported. Splice Machine has extensive online documentation on importing options and best practices.

Important: the flat files you use to import should be delimited (using comma, etc.), with newlines between each record.

To copy your database to S3, you need to have an AWS account with access to S3 buckets.

If you need assistance with copying your data to S3, please visit our splice-community Slack channel; if you've not already done so, you can register for this channel here.

Copying Small Files From Your Local Machine

For small files on your local machine, you may be able to use the AWS Web UI to upload your files:

  1. Log in to your AWS account
  2. Navigate to the S3 area
  3. Create an S3 bucket, if necessary
  4. Navigate to your S3 bucket
  5. Click the Upload button
  6. Select the files to copy or use drag-and-drop to copy them to S3"

Copying Large Files

The files that you want to import into your database are typically large and not located on your local computer; this makes it necessary to use the AWS Command Line Interface to copy these files to S3.

The AWS CLI site, https://aws.amazon.com/cli/, shows you how to install and use this interface to copy your data up to an S3 bucket. Pr

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Where to Go Next

Now that you've learned about preparing your data to import into your Splice Machine database, please continue on to the [*Importing Data*](/#/notebook/2DVR1D5BP) notebook.

msg.data:
Where to Go Next

Now that you’ve learned about preparing your data to import into your Splice Machine database, please continue on to the Importing Data notebook.

paragraphs.text: %md ## Related Documentation The Importing Data Tutorial in our documentation provides details about and examples of using our different data importation processes.

msg.data:
Related Documentation

The Importing Data Tutorial in our documentation provides details about and examples of using our different data importation processes.

name: Splice Machine Training/For Developers, Part I - Beginning/c. Preparing Data for Import
